t: Genesis 49
Jacob Blesses His Sons
Then*p Jacob called for his sons and said: “Gather around so I can tell you what will happen to you in days to come.
“Assemble*pn and listen, sons of Jacob; listen*ld to your father Israel.
“Reuben,*pn you are my firstborn, my*ld might, the first sign of my strength, excelling*ld in honor, excelling in power.
Turbulent*ln as the waters, you will no longer excel, for*ld you went up onto your father’s bed, onto*ld my couch and defiled it.
“Simeon*pn and Levi are brothers— their*ld swords are weapons of violence.
Let*ln me not enter their council, let*ld me not join their assembly, for*ln they have killed men in their anger and*ld hamstrung oxen as they pleased.
Cursed*ln be their anger, so fierce, and*ld their fury, so cruel! I*ln will scatter them in Jacob and*ld disperse them in Israel.
“Judah,*pn your brothers will praise you; your*ld hand will be on the neck of your enemies; your*ld father’s sons will bow down to you.
You*ln are a lion’s cub, Judah; you*ld return from the prey, my son. Like*ln a lion he crouches and lies down, like*ld a lioness—who dares to rouse him?
The*ln scepter will not depart from Judah, nor*ld the ruler’s staff from between his feet, until*ln he to whom it belongs shall come and*ld the obedience of the nations shall be his.
He*ln will tether his donkey to a vine, his*ld colt to the choicest branch; he*ln will wash his garments in wine, his*ld robes in the blood of grapes.
His*ln eyes will be darker than wine, his*ld teeth whiter than milk.
“Zebulun*pn will live by the seashore and*ld become a haven for ships; his*ld border will extend toward Sidon.
“Issachar*pn is a rawboned donkey lying*ld down among the sheep pens.
When*ln he sees how good is his resting place and*ld how pleasant is his land, he*ln will bend his shoulder to the burden and*ld submit to forced labor.
“Dan*pn will provide justice for his people as*ld one of the tribes of Israel.
Dan*ln will be a snake by the roadside, a*ld viper along the path, that*ln bites the horse’s heels so*ld that its rider tumbles backward.
“I*pn look for your deliverance, Lord.*s
“Gad*pn will be attacked by a band of raiders, but*ld he will attack them at their heels.
“Asher’s*pn food will be rich; he*ld will provide delicacies fit for a king.
“Naphtali*pn is a doe set free that*ld bears beautiful fawns.
“Joseph*pn is a fruitful vine, a*ld fruitful vine near a spring, whose*ld branches climb over a wall.
With*ln bitterness archers attacked him; they*ld shot at him with hostility.
But*ln his bow remained steady, his*ld strong arms stayed limber, because*ln of the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob, because*ld of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,

because*ln of your father’s God, who helps you, because*ld of the Almighty, who blesses you with*ln blessings of the skies above, blessings*ld of the deep springs below, blessings*ld of the breast and womb.

Your*ln father’s blessings are greater than*ld the blessings of the ancient mountains, than*ld the bounty of the age-old hills. Let*ln all these rest on the head of Joseph, on*ld the brow of the prince among his brothers.
“Benjamin*pn is a ravenous wolf; in*ld the morning he devours the prey, in*ld the evening he divides the plunder.”
All*p these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he blessed them, giving each the blessing appropriate to him.
The Death of Jacob
Then*p he gave them these instructions: “I am about to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
There Abraham and his wife Sarah were buried, there Isaac and his wife Rebekah were buried, and there I buried Leah.
The field and the cave in it were bought from the Hittites.”
When*p Jacob had finished giving instructions to his sons, he drew his feet up into the bed, breathed his last and was gathered to his people.
